conclusion: The light source is positioned in front of the objects, casting shadows behind them.
The shadows A, B, C, and D are formed on the ground due to the obstruction of light by the objects.
When the light source moves backward, it increases the distance between the light source and the objects.
This change affects the angle at which the light rays hit the objects and the ground.
As the light source moves backward, the angle of the light rays hitting the birdcage decreases.
This results in a shorter shadow because the light rays are more parallel to the ground.
The shadow will also shift slightly forward as the light source moves backward.
Similar to Shadow A, the angle of the light rays hitting the knife decreases.
The shadow will become shorter and shift slightly forward.
The angle of the light rays hitting the candlestick decreases.
The shadow will become shorter and shift slightly forward.
The angle of the light rays hitting the box and matches decreases.
The shadow will become shorter and shift slightly forward.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will become shorter.
All shadows will shift slightly forward on the ground.
When the light source moves backward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will become shorter and shift slightly forward on the ground.
